solution:
We see that $f(n) = n + 10$ for $n = 1,$ 2, 3, $\dots,$ 9.  Then
\begin{align*}
f(10) &= f(5) = 15, \\
f(11) &= f(6) = 16, \\
f(12) &= f(7) = 17, \\
f(13) &= f(8) = 18, \\
f(14) &= f(9) = 19, \\
f(15) &= f(10) = 15,
\end{align*}and so on.  At this point, the function becomes periodic, with period 5.  Therefore, the maximum value of the function is $\boxed{19}.$
socratic_questions:
1. What is the definition of the function $f$? 
2. Can you find any pattern or regularity in the function values for $n < 10$? 
3. What happens to the function values when $n$ is greater than or equal to 10? 
4. How does the value of $f(n)$ relate to the value of $f(n-5)$ when $n \geq 10$? 
5. Is it possible for the function $f$ to have a maximum value? Why or why not? 
6. Can you identify the period of the function after it becomes periodic when $n\geq 10$? 
7. Can you explain why the maximum value of the function is equal to 19? 
8. Are there any other interesting properties or characteristics of this function that you have noticed?
